title-group.article-title: Effect of an Isolated Shell on Interior Noise Levels in a Turboprop Aircraft

permissions.copyright-statement: Copyright 1990 Society of Automotive Engineers, Inc.

abstract.p: A noise control strategy for a small twin engine turboprop aircraft is evaluated. The noise control strategy consisted of a composite shell suspended inside the aircraft on isolation mounts. The evaluation consisted of a ground test program on component panels to select the shell material and a flight test program on the aircraft with and without the interior shell installed. Results from both phases are presented.

ref.mixed-citation: Metzger, F.B., "Strategies for Aircraft Interior Noise Reduction in Existing and Future Propeller Aircraft," presented at SAE Business Aircraft Meeting, Wichita, Kansas, April 1981.
Navaneethan, R., "General Aviation Aircraft Interior Noise Problem: Some Suggested Solutions," DE Project Report, University of Kansas, Lawrence, Kansas, June 1984.
Holmer, C.I., "Alternate Approach to Aircraft Interior Noise Control I - Damped Trim Panels," AIAA Paper No. 84-237-1, October 1984.

Sykes, A.O., "The Evaluation of Mounts Isolating Nonrigid Machines From Nonrigid Foundations," presented at a special session of the ASME Applied Mechanics Division Conference at the University of Illinois, June 14-16, 1956.
Cremer, J., Heckl, M., Ungar, E. E., Structure-Borne Sound, Springer-Verlag, New York, N.Y., 1973
